Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> There were some conversations on here a couple days ago about how pools might be set up while new blocks are so time locked, not sure if that will happen before the time locks end out not. In any case the time locks will be off after the next having, I believe in about 2-3 weeks. I'm not at my computer, so harder to check at the moment. Once the that happens pools will be much safer and more straightforward, and we expect to see multiple pools pop up. We also intend to have an official pool sorry after that.

Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> @miketout to confirm something thats been a little confusing and not clear on the blockchain explorer. ... is it 1440/day to POS and 1440/day to POW?
each mined block is getting 192.. not shared.... but I'm not seeing an equlivant POS share for that block
are the POS shares clumped into block payouts?

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Gmoney 50% of blocks go to POS, but the hash rate for POW can still be calculated with 1440 due to the way the difficulty algorithms work

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> @miketout  ok thanks. yes that the main thing that I needed to know. My hash formula is using 1440

Author: Gateway#3763

Will anything with the switch at block 67680 go to fix any distribution issues? Do you have any toughts on this?

A bunch of junk machines I have have been picking up the slack for all the big machines, so it hasnt been a total loss, but I'm off a few blocks a day for sure for sure, even thogh hashrate has long since stabalized.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I am pulling as much data as I can to analyze it. I am not seeing anything too odd that lasts for too long.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> @miketout .. does the ping time to your connected miner nodes affect your ability to deliver hash?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> if someone spikes in a big way on hash rate, they could theoretically take a few more blocks and then drop off completely and let others take less as the difficulty adjusts. with the POS, they should be thwarted from really messing with the chain too much, and even with a big spike, the POS should prevent them from getting over 51%. since we've been low on POS, there's been an opening for more than 51%, but that is closing in a little over an hour

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> and to get that, someone would have needed a huge hash spike

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that we haven't seen

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> and regarding ping time.. Is it possible to blacklist slow server and whitelist fast servers to end up with any competitive advantage?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> the calculated diff takes a long time to adjust down after a big hashrate spike comes in and goes away. the PoS blocks solve the high diff to slow down the diff from dropping

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> It is certainly possible to grab maybe 10% of the nethash, but it would be a big costly undertaking. Getting 50%+ would take a team of people and a few thousand $.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> ping time doesn't affect your ability to deliver hash, but you could certainly waste time hashing on stale chain tips or not get your blocks submitted without long delays and have them orphaned

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> also the hashrate spike doesnt immediately reflect in higher diff, but I have seen a dramatic drop in my PoW blocks found, which then is followed by a hashrate increase. this is just a delay in the block time diff adjusting and on the way up, likely the PoS mechanism is also dampening the change

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> That is one question I had about how the algo decides the winner. Is the first to report back or the one with a solve and the lowest timestamp.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Gmoney we are considering ways to improve the p2p network, and QoS is an important factor.
@jl777c VerusPoS should exactly follow PoW, not dampening, nor destabilizing PoW response on difficulty, but interfering with any attempt to mess with time stamps or get more than 51%

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> Network could be an issue.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> PoW diff adjustment to real hashrate and solve times just has some latency

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> yes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> and with PoS getting half the blocks, it seems it will slow down things by 50%

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> how many blocks does the diff algo take into account?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Gmoney with PoS, it's a little complicated

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> i dont think it is a bad thing, it is just what it is and has a longer latency that pure PoW

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> in one sense, 45, in another many more

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> yes within 100 blocks it is adjusting pretty well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i don't think PoS will slow response

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> it's just a different algo than the normal Digishield in Zcash

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> PoS can affect adjustment, but equally all the time, regardless of hashrate changes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so, in one sense, you could say that it does

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> well I have experienced cases where the real hashrate is drastically lower than the diff, and PoS blocks are coming in ave 60 seconds, but if pure PoW they wouldnt have. if PoS is assuming the hashrate is the diff and the hashrate is lower than diff, it slows down

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> k.. ya that generally lets me know.. 100 isnt that great.. a hash spike is out within 2 hours then (or less) so shouldnt be an issue why it coinsided with days of lower POW blocks for many..

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> but it does when the hashrate is stable or when climbing or dropping

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> 45

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> for PoW, it uses 45 for averaging, but the PoS relative difficulty can go much longer and is often 90. PoW should respond in 45

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> but PoS randomizes its response a little

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> always

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> but with big spikes, it may take 100

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> to stabilize, but this is pretty common

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> still low.. 120 for most equihash coins.. 720 for monero..etc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> and would be like that without the PoS as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jl777c> yes, it seems responsive enough

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Steve666> Is there anyway to see how many coins are being staked? That could explain the spikes somewhat if someone is not staking 24/7 and has lots of coins

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> staking won't change that way. it is completely relative to PoW at every block

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i don't know of a way to see either, because the only time you see is when someone submits a PoS block

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gmoney> Ok anyways @miketout  I think its worthwile to look into the ability to deliver equal distribution across the P2P network. Perhaps studing ip addresses.... Although that would only be useful if it could be correlated with hashrates to see if anyone really is getting a network competitive advantage.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Steve666> I thought staking is 50% of the hash rate, thus if someone were to stake more for a short period wouldnt the hash rate adjust?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> I would suspect network latency as an issue. Everything else seems solid. Even 100ms can be big.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> staking difficulty is completely relative to PoW and could make a short term change, but should be quickly adjusted for. i guess if someone took huge amounts off completely and back on, but it uses an exponentially adjusted, linear weighted moving average to take into account bursts and adjust more quickly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i would also suspect network latency may be an issue, as there are definite ways it could have an impact. i think if it is the issue, it could be solved with a way to discover and further decentralize trustworthy nodes, which I've been thinking of, as well as eigentrust++ types of approach with QoS

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> but @Steve666 you could also have a point with big changes in staking supply

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i can't rule it out without more study, i should say

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Steve666> That is the only thing that would make sense to me, because it has always declined after a while.
